name: 2,7-dimethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrido[2,3-g]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3324

name: 2,7-dimethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrido[2,3-g]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3324
Reason: The target compound is based on a pyridoquinoline structure which we can compare to quinoline itself to start with. The melting point of quinoline is approximately 237°C. A tetrahydropyrido group reduces rigidity and introduces more flexibility compared to quinoline, which typically lowers the melting point due to less efficient stacking and packing of the molecules (-50°C). Each methyl (CH3) group has a small impact on the melting point; the effect can vary slightly depending on the compound structure but generally, alkyl groups can increase the melting point by providing more surface area for van der Waals interactions. For aromatic systems, the methyl group increase may be less pronounced than in aliphatic systems but it is reasonable to estimate an increase of about +5°C per methyl group. Here we have 2 methyl groups, so that adds (2 x +5°C) to the prediction. Therefore, overall decreases due to flexibility but increases from the alkyl groups are factored in.

name: 2,7-dimethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrido[2,3-g]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3324
Reason: The target compound is based on a pyridoquinoline structure which we can compare to quinoline itself to start with. The melting point of quinoline is approximately 237°C. A tetrahydropyrido group reduces rigidity and introduces more flexibility compared to quinoline, which typically lowers the melting point due to less efficient stacking and packing of the molecules (-66°C). Each methyl (CH3) group has a small impact on the melting point; the effect can vary slightly depending on the compound structure but generally, alkyl groups can increase the melting point by providing more surface area for van der Waals interactions. For aromatic systems, the methyl group increase may be less pronounced than in aliphatic systems but it is reasonable to estimate an increase of about +4°C per methyl group. Here we have 2 methyl groups, so that adds (2 x +4°C) to the prediction. Therefore, overall decreases due to flexibility but increases from the alkyl groups are factored in.
